definition: A lightweight thread of execution managed by the Go runtime, started with the go keyword
A typed conduit for sending and receiving values between goroutines using the <- operator
A keyword that schedules a function call to run when the surrounding function returns
A type that specifies a set of method signatures, satisfied implicitly by any type implementing those methods
A composite type that groups together fields with different types under a single name
A dynamically-sized flexible view into an underlying array, declared as []T
A built-in hash table type that associates keys with values, declared as map[K]V
sync.Mutex provides mutual exclusion locking to protect shared state from concurrent access
sync.WaitGroup waits for a collection of goroutines to finish, using Add, Done, and Wait methods
The context package carries deadlines, cancellation signals, and request-scoped values across API boundaries
A control structure that lets a goroutine wait on multiple channel operations simultaneously
A built-in function that stops normal execution and begins unwinding the stack
A built-in function that regains control of a panicking goroutine, only useful inside deferred functions
A special function that runs automatically before main, used for package-level initialization
A predeclared identifier used in const declarations to generate incrementing integer values
An alias for int32 representing a Unicode code point
An alias for uint8, commonly used for raw data and string contents
The zero value for pointers, interfaces, maps, slices, channels, and function types
A built-in function that allocates and initializes slices, maps, and channels
A built-in function that allocates memory for a type and returns a pointer to its zero value
A built-in function that adds elements to the end of a slice, growing it if necessary
A keyword used in for loops to iterate over slices, maps, strings, and channels
The go keyword starts a new goroutine running a function call concurrently
The channel type keyword, used to declare typed channels for goroutine communication
A channel with capacity that allows sends without a ready receiver, created with make(chan T, size)
A channel with no capacity where send and receive block until both sides are ready
A synchronization primitive that ensures a function is executed exactly once across all goroutines
A concurrent-safe map implementation from the sync package for use with multiple goroutines
A pool of temporary objects that can be reused to reduce garbage collection pressure
golang.org/x/sync/errgroup manages a group of goroutines and collects the first error returned
A built-in interface type with a single Error() string method, used for representing failure conditions
Creates a formatted error string, supports %w verb for wrapping errors in an error chain
Reports whether any error in a chain matches a target, used for sentinel error comparison
Finds the first error in a chain that matches a target type and sets the target variable
A fundamental interface with a Read method for reading bytes from a source
A fundamental interface with a Write method for writing bytes to a destination
An interface combining io.Reader and io.Closer, commonly returned by HTTP response bodies
An interface with ServeHTTP method that responds to HTTP requests
An adapter type that allows ordinary functions to be used as HTTP handlers
The default HTTP request multiplexer that matches URL patterns to handlers
Encodes a Go value into JSON bytes using struct tags for field name mapping
Decodes JSON bytes into a Go value, using struct tags to map JSON keys to fields
Backtick annotations like json:"name" that control JSON field naming and behavior
A compiler directive that embeds files into the Go binary at compile time as strings or byte slices
The module system for dependency management, using go.mod and go.sum files
The file that defines a module path and its dependency requirements
The file that contains cryptographic checksums of module dependencies for verification
A high-performance RPC framework using protocol buffers, commonly used in Go microservices
Protocol Buffers, a binary serialization format used with gRPC for defining service interfaces
A popular Go library for creating CLI applications with commands, flags, and subcommands
A Go configuration library that reads from files, environment variables, and remote config systems
A high-performance HTTP web framework for Go with a martini-like API
An ORM library for Go that provides a developer-friendly interface for database operations
A testing toolkit with assertions, mocks, and test suite support for Go
A powerful URL router and dispatcher for Go HTTP servers
Uber's structured, leveled logging library for Go with high performance
Extracts the concrete value from an interface using value.(Type) syntax
A switch statement that compares types instead of values, using value.(type) syntax
Including one struct or interface inside another to inherit its methods and fields
A method receiver declared as *T that can modify the original struct value
A method receiver declared as T that operates on a copy of the struct
